#Text=Taal Volcano
#Text=Taal Volcano is a complex stratovolcano in the province of Batangas , Philippines .
#Text=The volcano , together with the lake and its approximately radius , forms the larger Taal Volcano Natural Park , officially the Taal Volcano Protected Landscape ( TVPL ) .
#Text=The nearest town , and the usual base for trips to the volcano , is Tagaytay in Cavite province .
#Text=Talisay , within the park boundaries , is the nearest town at the Batangas side ; the boats on the package tours depart from there , but it 's possible to get there without going to Tagaytay .
#Text=The scenic historic town of Taal is covered in a separate article ; it was built some distance away after a volcanic eruption wiped out an older town in 1755 .
#Text=Cities and towns

#Text=Taal Volcano is often said to be only the Volcano Proper and the surrounding lake , but the park covers also some towns and cities ( not necessarily including the central settlement or downtown ) within an approximately radius
#Text=— The main gateway to Volcano Island .
#Text=It is a small town , with few sights in itself , except for the volcano .
#Text=—
#Text=Another town to the west of Talisay , again with a few sights
#Text=— A smaller city , with a medium-sized downtown with an old church at its middle .
#Text=Tanauan 's designated tourism zone , with some lakeside resorts , once has the original town that was destroyed by the 1755 eruption .
#Text=— Batangas 's largest city and economic center .
#Text=Our Lipa guide also covers the lakeside towns of :
#Text=— Rural municipality with a town center bordering Lipa .
#Text=Northward towards the lake are some inland resorts , some with views of the lake .
#Text=The original town of Lipa used to be in here until the 1755 eruption .
#Text=—
#Text=A lakeside town , with some resorts , and a park at the lakefront .
#Text=To the east of the town is Marian Orchard , a serene religious site at the middle of the jungle running down the slopes to the lakeshore .
#Text=— Has Mount Maculot , a peak popular with beginner hikers .
#Text=The town is really small , and not much to see , but it has plenty of inland resorts .

#Text=Tagaytay in Cavite province is the usual base for trips to the volcano , but our guide only covers the park area within Batangas province and the two towns where the boats depart , Talisay and Laurel , which are too small to have their own guides .
#Text=Understand
#Text=Taal Volcano is best known as the world 's smallest volcano , and one known example of " a lake with a volcano with a lake " .
#Text=It is an active volcano , with a history of 33 recorded eruptions .
#Text=It is the second most active volcano in the Philippines , after Mount Mayon , and is one of the " Decade Volcanoes " .
#Text=Taal Volcano is part of a chain of volcanoes that have existed since prehistoric times , resulting from the subduction of the Eurasian Plate and Pacific Plate .
#Text=Trips to the volcano usually start from Tagaytay , a highland city in Cavite with other picturesque landscapes nearby .
#Text=Package tours to Taal Volcano are available from the city .
#Text=Taal Volcano is also one of the provincial symbols of Batangas , appearing on the new provincial seal and flag .
#Text=The volcano and the lake form the larger Taal Volcano Natural Park , officially the Taal Volcano Protected Landscape ( TVPL ) , which is designated as a national park since 1967 .
#Text=The national park covers an area within a radius of about from the caldera lake .
#Text=History
#Text=Taal Volcano is an active volcano , with its earliest recorded eruption in 1572 .
#Text=The lake and the volcano were first named as Bonbon ( or Bombón ) , which also gave the historical names of the present-day town of Taal and the province of Batangas .
#Text=Taal Volcano 's most destructive eruptions occurred in 1755 and 1910 .

#Text=The very destructive 1755 eruption destroyed the original downtown of Taal , now part of the little town of San Nicolas , as well as the original town center of present-day Lipa , now part of the town of Mataasnakahoy , and is well recorded in an account by a Spanish priest .
#Text=Ash and mud from the 1755 eruption were also carried by storms into the village of Caysasay ( present-day Taal ) and as far as Balayan .
#Text=Landscape
#Text=The volcano proper forms the Volcano Island , composed of seven volcanic cones and the caldera lake .
#Text=Taal Lake also forms the volcano , making the system complex .

#Text=Volcanic activity can be noticed through changes in Taal Lake ; some fish kill incidents on the lake are blamed on volcanic activity , though overcrowded fish pens ( baklad ) are often the cause .
#Text=From Tagaytay , Taal Volcano , alongside Taal Lake , dominate the landscape , with the dormant cone Binintiang Malaki being the most prominent .
#Text=The volcano is covered by vegetation up to the tree line at the crater lake .
#Text=On the base are some villages relying on fishing in Taal Lake and agriculture in the fertile soil of Volcano Island .
#Text=Flora and fauna
#Text=Taal Lake is home to the tawilis ( Sardinella tawilis ) , a species of sardine endemic to the lake .

#Text=It is often served as a local dish in the surrounding area , but overfishing is threatening the tawilis population , so it was designated an endangered species in 2019 by the International Union for the Conservation of Nature ( IUCN ) , and a closed season is implemented to allow the fish to increase in number .
#Text=Get in
#Text=Taal Volcano is one of the most accessible in Luzon island , and many tourists , local and foreign , go here , usually in package tours from Tagaytay .
#Text=Peak season traffic can be high , and tours can get fully booked .

#Text=It is possible to just see the volcano and the lake without getting further into Volcano Island , or have a do-it-yourself tour , avoiding completely Tagaytay where the package tour providers are based and getting directly into the boats in Talisay or Laurel .
#Text=The nearest airport is in Manila , and the closest seaport is in Batangas City .
#Text=From either way , there is public transportation into the jump-off points .
#Text=By car

#Text=Most visitors will come to Tagaytay by car , and there , they will purchase the tour packages to Taal , but it 's possible to get into the towns directly without dealing with the tour operators .
#Text=Talisay can be reached directly via Talisay-Tanauan Road , which can be accessed from STAR Tollway at Tanauan .
#Text=From Tagaytay , Talisay-Tagaytay Road runs through jungle at the mountain slopes down to the lakeside , where it joins Talisay-Tanauan and Talisay-Laurel roads .

#Text=Talisay-Tagaytay and Talisay-Tanauan roads are both numbered as Route 421 , but the route number signs do n't say where you should turn to Talisay town proper , so from Tagaytay , watch for signs that point to Tanauan .
